5 Lists

Pyret lists are defined by a Pyret data structure, and come with a number of built-in functions and methods.

5.1 List

5.1.1 The List Datatype

Pyret lists are defined via a data declaration:

List

data List: | empty | link(cyclic first :: Any, cyclic rest :: List) end

5.1.2 List Methods

List instances have a number of methods. The following methods are defined on all lists (instances of empty and link):

List.length

method(self):  end

List.each

method(self, f):  end

List.map

method(self, f):  end

List.filter

method(self, f):  end

List.find

method(self, f):  end

List.partition

method(self, f):  end

List.foldr

method(self, f, base):  end

List.foldl

method(self, f, base):  end

List.member

method(self, elt):  end

List.append

method(self, other):  end

List.last

method(self):  end

List.take

method(self, n):  end

List.drop

method(self, n):  end

List.reverse

method(self):  end

List.get

method(self, n):  end

List.set

method(self, n, e):  end

List._equals

method(self, other):  end

List.tostring

method(self):  end

List._torepr

method(self):  end

List.sort-by

method(self, cmp, eq):  end

Takes a comparator to check for elements that are strictly greater or less than one another, and an equality procedure for elements that are equal, and sorts the list accordingly. The sort is not guaranteed to be stable.
List.sort

method(self):  end

List.join-str

method(self, str):  end

5.2 list functions

In Captain Teach and in #lang pyret/whalesong, these are in the environment by default, so you can just use their names as identifiers.

All of the functions in this section are available on the list object, and help manipulate lists.

range

fun range(start, stop):  end

Creates a list of numbers, starting with start, ending with stop-1

repeat

fun repeat(n :: Number, e :: Any) -> List:

  

where:

  repeat(0, 10) is []

  repeat(3, -1) is [-1, -1, -1]

  repeat(1, 'foo') is ['foo']

end

Creates a list with n copies of e

filter

fun filter(f, lst :: List):  end

Returns the subset of lst for which f(elem) is true

partition

fun partition(f, lst :: List):  end

Splits the list into two lists, one for which f(elem) is true, and one for which f(elem) is false

split-at

fun split-at(n :: Number, lst :: List) -> { prefix :: List, suffix :: List }:

  

end

Splits the list into two lists, one containing the first n elements, and the other containing the rest

any

fun any(f :: ( Any -> Bool ), lst :: List) -> Bool:

  

where:

  any(fun(n): n > 1 end, [1, 2, 3]) is true

  any(fun(n): n > 3 end, [1, 2, 3]) is false

  any(fun(x): true end, []) is false

  any(fun(x): false end, []) is false

end

Returns true if f(elem) returns true for any elem of lst

find

fun find(f :: ( Any -> Bool ), lst :: List) -> Option:

  

where:

  find(fun(elt): elt > 1 end, [1, 2, 3]) is some(2)

  find(fun(elt): true end, ['find-me']) is some('find-me')

  find(fun(elt): elt > 4 end, [1, 2, 3]) is none

  find(fun(elt): true end, []) is none

  find(fun(elt): false end, []) is none

  find(fun(elt): false end, [1]) is none

end

Returns some(elem) where elem is the first elem in lst for which f(elem) returns true, or none otherwise

map

fun map(f, lst :: List):  end

Returns a list made up of f(elem) for each elem in lst

map2

fun map2(f, l1 :: List, l2 :: List):  end

Returns a list made up of f(elem1, elem2) for each elem1 in l1, elem2 in l2

map3

fun map3(f, l1 :: List, l2 :: List, l3 :: List):  end

Returns a list made up of f(e1, e2, e3) for each e1 in l1, e2 in l2, e3 in l3

map4

fun map4(f, l1 :: List, l2 :: List, l3 :: List, l4 :: List):  end

Returns a list made up of f(e1, e2, e3, e4) for each e1 in l1, e2 in l2, e3 in l3, e4 in l4

map_n

fun map_n(f, n :: Number, lst :: List):  end

Returns a list made up of f(n, e1), f(n+1, e2) .. for e1, e2 ... in lst

map2_n

fun map2_n(f, n :: Number, l1 :: List, l2 :: List):  end

map3_n

fun map3_n(f, n :: Number, l1 :: List, l2 :: List, l3 :: List):  end

map4_n

fun map4_n(f, n :: Number, l1 :: List, l2 :: List, l3 :: List, l4 :: List):

  

end

each

fun each(f, lst :: List):  end

Calls f for each elem in lst, and returns nothing

each2

fun each2(f, lst1 :: List, lst2 :: List):  end

Calls f on each pair of corresponding elements in l1 and l2, and returns nothing. Stops after the shortest list

each3

fun each3(f, lst1 :: List, lst2 :: List, lst3 :: List):  end

Calls f on each triple of corresponding elements in l1, l2 and l3, and returns nothing. Stops after the shortest list

each4

fun each4(f, lst1 :: List, lst2 :: List, lst3 :: List, lst4 :: List):  end

Calls f on each tuple of corresponding elements in l1, l2, l3 and l4, and returns nothing. Stops after the shortest list

each_n

fun each_n(f, num :: Number, lst :: List):  end

each2_n

fun each2_n(f, num :: Number, lst1 :: List, lst2 :: List):  end

each3_n

fun each3_n(f, num :: Number, lst1 :: List, lst2 :: List, lst3 :: List):  end

each4_n

fun each4_n(

    f,

    num :: Number,

    lst1 :: List,

    lst2 :: List,

    lst3 :: List,

    lst4 :: List

  ):

  

end

fold

fun fold(f, base, lst :: List):  end

fold2

fun fold2(f, base, l1 :: List, l2 :: List):  end

fold3

fun fold3(f, base, l1 :: List, l2 :: List, l3 :: List):  end

fold4

fun fold4(f, base, l1 :: List, l2 :: List, l3 :: List, l4 :: List):  end

index

fun index(l :: List, n :: Number):

  

where:

  l0 = []

  l1 = [1]

  l2 = [{ 'some': 'object' }, { 'some-other': 'object' }]

  l3 = ['a', 'b', 'c']

  index(l0, 1) raises 'list too short'

  index(l1, 0) is 1

  index(l2, 1) is { 'some-other': 'object' }

  index(l3, 2) is 'c'

end
